title: Psalms Chapter 140 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 140 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 140 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 140.

questions.question: From whom does David ask the LORD to deliver him in Psalms 140:1?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:1 says, 'Deliver me, O LORD, from the evil man.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 140:3, what have the wicked sharpened like a serpent?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:3 states, 'They have sharpened their tongues like a serpent.'

questions.question: What does the Psalmist ask the LORD to keep him from in Psalms 140:4?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:4 says, 'Keep me, O LORD, from the hands of the wicked.'

questions.question: What have the proud hidden for the Psalmist according to Psalms 140:5?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:5 states, 'The proud have hid a snare for me, and cords.'

questions.question: In Psalms 140:6, to whom does the Psalmist say, 'Thou art my God'?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:6 says, 'I said unto the LORD, Thou art my God.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 140:7, what has God covered in the day of battle?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:7 states, 'Thou hast covered my head in the day of battle.'

questions.question: What does the Psalmist ask the LORD not to grant to the wicked in Psalms 140:8?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:8 says, 'Grant not, O LORD, the desires of the wicked.'

questions.question: What does the Psalmist ask to fall upon those who compass him about in Psalms 140:10?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:10 states, 'Let burning coals fall upon them.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 140:11, who will evil hunt to overthrow?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:11 says, 'Evil shall hunt the violent man to overthrow him.'

questions.question: Who does the Psalmist say the LORD will maintain the cause of in Psalms 140:12?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:12 states, 'The LORD will maintain the cause of the afflicted, and the right of the poor.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 140:1 asks the LORD to preserve the Psalmist from the violent man.
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:1 says, 'preserve me from the violent man.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 140:8, the Psalmist asks the LORD to further the wicked device.
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:8 requests, 'Grant not the desires of the wicked: further not his wicked device.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 140:13 says the upright shall dwell in the presence of the LORD.
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:13 states, 'the upright shall dwell in thy presence.'

questions.question: Complete the verse from Psalms 140:7: 'O GOD the Lord, the strength of my salvation, thou hast covered my ______ in the day of battle.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:7 says, 'thou hast covered my head in the day of battle.'

questions.question: Complete the verse from Psalms 140:6: 'I said unto the LORD, Thou art my ______: hear the voice of my supplications, O LORD.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:6 states, 'Thou art my God.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 140 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 140 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 140, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God during difficult times?
options: God is our strength and protector in times of battle.
We should rely on our own strength to overcome evil.
God abandons us when troubles arise.
The wicked will always succeed against the righteous.
questions.correctAnswer: God is our strength and protector in times of battle.
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:7 says, 'O GOD the Lord, the strength of my salvation, thou hast covered my head in the day of battle,' highlighting God's protection and strength during trials. This is supported by verses 1-4 which emphasize deliverance and protection from evil.

questions.question: How does Psalms 140 teach us about dealing with enemies who plot evil against us?
options: Trust God to protect and deliver from violent and wicked men.
Ignore the problem and do nothing.
Join in their plans to avoid harm.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to protect and deliver from violent and wicked men.
questions.explanation: Verses 1-5 show a plea for God's protection from wicked and violent men who plot mischief. The psalmist trusts God to keep him safe rather than taking matters into his own hands.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with bitterness toward someone who speaks evil about them. Based on Psalms 140, what biblical principle would you share?
options: Trust God to bring justice and let His judgment fall.
Return evil with evil to protect yourself.
Ignore the situation and pretend it does not hurt.
Confront them aggressively to stop the gossip.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to bring justice and let His judgment fall.
questions.explanation: Verses 9-11 describe how the psalmist asks God to let the mischief of their own lips cover the enemies and to not establish evil speakers. This shows reliance on God's justice rather than personal retaliation.

questions.question: How does Psalms 140 encourage believers to maintain integrity and honesty in daily life?
options: By trusting God to uphold the cause of the afflicted and poor.
By hiding from those who do wrong.
By joining in with those who plot evil.
By ignoring injustice and focusing on self.
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting God to uphold the cause of the afflicted and poor.
questions.explanation: Verse 12 declares that the LORD will maintain the cause of the afflicted and the right of the poor, encouraging believers to live with integrity and trust God's justice in daily life.

questions.question: What does Psalms 140 teach about prayer and personal devotion?
options: We should earnestly call on God as our personal God in times of trouble.
Prayer is unnecessary because God does not hear us.
Prayer is only for public worship, not personal struggles.
We should pray only when we feel like it.
questions.correctAnswer: We should earnestly call on God as our personal God in times of trouble.
questions.explanation: Verse 6 shows the psalmist saying, 'I said unto the LORD, Thou art my God: hear the voice of my supplications,' emphasizing heartfelt prayer and personal devotion.

questions.question: How does Psalms 140 remind us to cultivate humility and contentment in the face of proud adversaries?
options: By trusting God to thwart the proud who set snares.
By boasting about our own strength.
By plotting against those who are proud.
By ignoring God’s role in justice.
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting God to thwart the proud who set snares.
questions.explanation: Verse 5 describes the proud hiding snares and nets, but the psalmist relies on God to protect him, teaching humility and contentment in God’s protection rather than prideful retaliation.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 140, it is appropriate to seek God’s help against violent and evil men who intend harm.
questions.explanation: Verses 1-4 show the psalmist pleading with God to deliver and preserve him from evil and violent men, encouraging believers to seek God's help in such circumstances.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 140 encourages believers to take personal revenge against those who do evil.
questions.explanation: The psalm calls on God to bring justice and not on the believer to take revenge (verses 8-11), emphasizing trust in God's righteous judgment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 140 teaches that the righteous shall ______ unto God's name and dwell in His presence.
questions.explanation: Verse 13 states, 'Surely the righteous shall give thanks unto thy name: the upright shall dwell in thy presence,' encouraging gratitude and fellowship with God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 140 instruct believers to respond when confronted with poisonous and deceitful speech?
options: Pray for God to cover the mischief of their lips.
Ignore the speech and tolerate it.
questions.correctAnswer: Pray for God to cover the mischief of their lips.
questions.explanation: Verse 9 asks God to let the mischief of the lips of those who compass the psalmist cover them, showing reliance on God rather than personal retaliation.

questions.question: What does Psalms 140 teach about perseverance through trials and trusting God’s justice?
options: God will maintain the cause of the afflicted and ensure justice.
Trials are a sign God has abandoned us.
We should give up when faced with adversity.
questions.correctAnswer: God will maintain the cause of the afflicted and ensure justice.
questions.explanation: Verse 12 confirms that the LORD maintains the cause of the afflicted and the right of the poor, encouraging perseverance and trust in God's justice.

questions.question: How does Psalms 140 encourage believers to maintain spiritual discipline in prayer?
options: By continually calling on God as our protector in times of danger.
By depending on people rather than God.
questions.correctAnswer: By continually calling on God as our protector in times of danger.
questions.explanation: The psalmist’s repeated calls to God for protection (verses 1-7) show the importance of persistent prayer and spiritual discipline.

questions.question: How does Psalms 140 reflect the biblical virtue of humility before God in the face of adversaries?
options: By acknowledging God as the strength of salvation and seeking His guidance.
By boasting about personal power over enemies.
By ignoring God and relying on self alone.
questions.correctAnswer: By acknowledging God as the strength of salvation and seeking His guidance.
questions.explanation: Verse 7 acknowledges God as the strength of salvation, demonstrating humility and reliance on God rather than self.

questions.question: What practical truth does Psalms 140 teach about generosity and stewardship in the presence of evil?
options: The righteous will dwell in God's presence and give thanks, encouraging faithfulness in stewardship.
Generosity is unnecessary when evil surrounds us.
Stewardship should be secret to avoid evil influence.
We should hoard resources to protect ourselves.
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous will dwell in God's presence and give thanks, encouraging faithfulness in stewardship.
questions.explanation: Verse 13 connects righteousness with dwelling in God's presence and giving thanks, which implies faithful living including stewardship.

questions.question: How does Psalms 140 teach us to handle temptation and evil devices from others?
options: Pray that God will not grant the desires or devices of the wicked.
Give in to temptation to avoid conflict.
Ignore the existence of evil devices.
Try to outsmart the wicked by your own schemes.
questions.correctAnswer: Pray that God will not grant the desires or devices of the wicked.
questions.explanation: Verse 8 says, 'Grant not, O LORD, the desires of the wicked: further not his wicked device,' teaching believers to pray against temptation and evil schemes.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 140 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 140.

questions.question: In Psalms 140:3, the psalmist compares the tongues of the wicked to what creature, and what is the significance of this imagery in the ancient Near Eastern context?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:3 states, 'They have sharpened their tongues like a serpent; adders' poison is under their lips.' In the ancient Near East, serpents commonly symbolized cunning and peril, highlighting the deceitful and harmful nature of the wicked's speech.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Psalms 140:1-5 to emphasize the danger posed by the wicked?
options: Parallelism, contrasting the violent and the righteous
Chiasm, framing the psalmist's plea with imagery of violence
Allegory, depicting the wicked as beasts
Typology, foreshadowing Christ's battle with evil
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm, framing the psalmist's plea with imagery of violence
questions.explanation: The structure in Psalms 140:1-5 uses chiasm by opening and closing with references to violent men and snares, framing the psalmist's prayer and emphasizing the perils faced (Psalms 140:1-5).

questions.question: According to Psalms 140:6, how does the psalmist address God, and what does this reveal about the author's relationship with God?
options: As 'Thou art my God,' showing personal trust and devotion
As 'Lord of Hosts,' emphasizing God's power
As 'King of Israel,' indicating national allegiance
As 'Judge of all,' reflecting divine justice
questions.correctAnswer: As 'Thou art my God,' showing personal trust and devotion
questions.explanation: In Psalms 140:6, the psalmist says, 'I said unto the LORD, Thou art my God,' expressing a personal and intimate relationship based on trust and reliance.

questions.question: Psalms 140:7 describes God as 'the strength of my salvation.' How does this phrase connect to the broader biblical theme of salvation?
options: It emphasizes God as protector and deliverer in times of battle
It refers exclusively to physical deliverance from enemies
It suggests salvation is earned by human strength
It indicates that salvation is a future event only
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes God as protector and deliverer in times of battle
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:7 states, 'O GOD the Lord, the strength of my salvation,' portraying God as the source of deliverance and protection, a theme consistent throughout Scripture where God saves His people from physical and spiritual enemies.

questions.question: In Psalms 140:8, the psalmist requests God not to grant the desires of the wicked. What theological concept does this request embody?
options: Divine justice and the prevention of wicked exaltation
questions.correctAnswer: Divine justice and the prevention of wicked exaltation
questions.explanation: The verse reads, 'Grant not, O LORD, the desires of the wicked: further not his wicked device,' reflecting a petition for divine justice to restrain evil and prevent the wicked from gaining power unjustly.

questions.question: Which Old Testament book shares a similar theme of God protecting the poor and oppressed as expressed in Psalms 140:12?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:12 states, 'I know that the LORD will maintain the cause of the afflicted, and the right of the poor.' Deuteronomy similarly emphasizes God's concern for justice and protection of the marginalized (e.g., Deuteronomy 10:18).

questions.question: What is the significance of the repeated use of 'Selah' in Psalms 140, particularly in verses 3, 5, and 8?
options: It signals a pause for meditation or musical interlude
It marks the end of the psalm
It indicates a change in speaker
It denotes a call to worship
questions.correctAnswer: It signals a pause for meditation or musical interlude
questions.explanation: 'Selah' appears thrice in Psalms 140 (verses 3, 5, and 8) and is traditionally understood as a liturgical or musical pause, inviting reflection on the preceding words.

questions.question: In Psalms 140:10, the psalmist prays that burning coals fall upon the wicked and that they be cast into deep pits. How does this imagery relate to ancient Near Eastern views of divine punishment?
options: Fire and pits symbolize total destruction and divine judgment
They are metaphors for exile to foreign lands
questions.correctAnswer: Fire and pits symbolize total destruction and divine judgment
questions.explanation: The imagery of burning coals and deep pits in Psalms 140:10 reflects ancient Near Eastern symbolism of divine wrath and complete destruction of enemies, expressing the psalmist’s desire for God's justice.

questions.question: How does the phrase 'the proud have hid a snare for me' in Psalms 140:5 connect with the broader biblical motif of pride leading to downfall?
options: It illustrates that pride causes people to plot harm and eventually leads to their own ruin
It suggests pride is a virtue rewarded by God
It indicates pride is unrelated to evil intentions
It portrays pride as a justification for violence
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates that pride causes people to plot harm and eventually leads to their own ruin
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:5 says, 'The proud have hid a snare for me,' linking pride with malicious plotting. This aligns with biblical teaching that pride is often the root of downfall (e.g., Proverbs 16:18).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 140 depicts the wicked as having sincere hearts and pure intentions.
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:2 states, 'Which imagine mischiefs in their heart,' indicating the wicked have evil intentions, not sincere or pure hearts.

questions.question: In Psalms 140:9, what is meant by 'let the mischief of their own lips cover them,' and how does this reflect a principle of poetic justice?
options: It means their own evil words will bring about their downfall
It means they will be physically covered by others
It suggests their lips will be silenced by God
It indicates their lies will be forgiven
questions.correctAnswer: It means their own evil words will bring about their downfall
questions.explanation: The verse calls for the wicked’s own harmful speech to ensnare them, reflecting poetic justice where one’s evil intentions rebound upon oneself.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage most directly echoes the plea for protection from evil speakers found in Psalms 140:11?
options: 2 Timothy 3:1-5, warning about evil men and deceivers
questions.correctAnswer: 2 Timothy 3:1-5, warning about evil men and deceivers
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:11 speaks of evil speakers and violent men being overthrown, a theme echoed in 2 Timothy 3:1-5, where Paul warns about perilous times with evil people and deceivers.

questions.question: What cultural or historical context underlies the psalmist's repeated references to snares, nets, and gins in Psalms 140:5?
options: These were common hunting traps in the ancient Near East symbolizing ambushes
They refer to ceremonial purification rites
They represent agricultural tools for harvest
They denote architectural terms for fortifications
questions.correctAnswer: These were common hunting traps in the ancient Near East symbolizing ambushes
questions.explanation: The imagery in Psalms 140:5 of snares and nets draws from common hunting practices in the ancient Near East, representing the secret and malicious traps set by enemies.

questions.question: In Psalms 140:13, what is the significance of the righteous dwelling in God's presence in relation to the psalm's overall theme of deliverance?
options: It signifies ultimate safety and reward for those who trust God
It implies physical relocation to a temple only
It suggests that righteousness requires isolation
It indicates that God's presence is distant
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies ultimate safety and reward for those who trust God
questions.explanation: The concluding verse, Psalms 140:13, states that the upright shall dwell in God's presence, symbolizing the fulfillment of deliverance and protection promised throughout the psalm.

questions.question: How does the plea for God to 'cover my head in the day of battle' in Psalms 140:7 reflect ancient Israelite warfare imagery?
options: It metaphorically asks for divine protection like a helmet in battle
It literally means wearing a physical helmet
It is a request for offensive strength only
It refers to a ritual of mourning
questions.correctAnswer: It metaphorically asks for divine protection like a helmet in battle
questions.explanation: The phrase in Psalms 140:7 uses the metaphor of God covering the psalmist's head as a helmet, symbolizing divine protection in spiritual and physical conflict, consistent with ancient warfare imagery.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 140 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 140 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 140:1, from whom does David ask the LORD to deliver him?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:1 explicitly states David's plea to be delivered from the evil man. This request aligns with other biblical passages where God is asked to protect from wickedness, such as Psalm 7:9, Proverbs 2:12, and 2 Thessalonians 3:3.

questions.question: What imagery is used in Psalms 140:3 to describe the speech of the wicked?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:3 describes the tongues of the wicked as sharpened like a serpent, with poison under their lips, illustrating their dangerous and deceitful speech. Similar imagery appears in Romans 3:13 and James 3:8, highlighting the corrupting power of evil speech.

questions.question: In Psalms 140:6, David refers to the LORD as what?
questions.explanation: David calls the LORD 'My God' in Psalms 140:6, expressing personal faith and dependence on God. This title reflects a covenant relationship seen throughout Scripture, such as in Exodus 20:2 and John 20:28.

questions.question: What does Psalms 140:7 say God has done for David in the day of battle?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:7 states that God has covered David's head in the day of battle, symbolizing protection and divine care. This theme of God's protective covering is echoed in Psalm 91:4 and Isaiah 59:17.

questions.question: What does David ask God not to grant to the wicked in Psalms 140:8?
questions.explanation: In Psalms 140:8, David petitions God not to grant the desires of the wicked nor further their devices, preventing their exaltation. This aligns with Proverbs 21:10 and James 4:3 concerning God’s justice against wicked ambitions.

questions.question: According to Psalms 140:12, what will the LORD maintain?
options: The cause of the afflicted and the right of the poor
questions.correctAnswer: The cause of the afflicted and the right of the poor
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:12 asserts that God maintains justice for the afflicted and the poor, emphasizing His role as the righteous judge who defends the oppressed. This is consistent with Isaiah 1:17, Psalm 82:3, Luke 4:18, and James 2:5.

questions.question: What punishment is invoked upon the enemies in Psalms 140:10?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:10 calls for burning coals to fall upon the enemies and for them to be cast into fire and deep pits, symbolizing divine judgment. This imagery parallels Nahum 1:6 and Revelation 20:10 regarding God's righteous wrath.

questions.question: Which phrase best describes the plan of the wicked as described in Psalms 140:5?
options: They have hid a snare and spread a net by the wayside
They have built a tower to heaven
They have sown seeds of peace
They have written laws of justice
questions.correctAnswer: They have hid a snare and spread a net by the wayside
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:5 speaks of the proud hiding snares and nets to trap the innocent, illustrating the deceitful and malicious intent of the wicked. This is reminiscent of Proverbs 12:13 and Matthew 26:4 where traps and snares symbolize evil schemes.

questions.question: In Psalms 140:4, David prays for preservation from violent men who have purposed what?
options: To exile me from the land
questions.explanation: David asks in Psalms 140:4 for God’s protection from violent men who intend to overthrow his steps or plans, reflecting the threat of sabotage against the believer’s journey. This echoes Psalm 37:23 and Jeremiah 15:21 regarding God's guidance and protection.

questions.question: What does Psalms 140:11 say about the fate of an evil speaker?
options: Let not an evil speaker be established in the earth
Let an evil speaker be crowned
Let an evil speaker be heard by all
Let an evil speaker be forgiven quickly
questions.correctAnswer: Let not an evil speaker be established in the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:11 petitions that an evil speaker not be established on earth, emphasizing the rejection of deceit and slander. This theme is consistent with Psalm 101:5 and Proverbs 10:18 which condemn malicious speech.

questions.question: How does Psalms 140:9 describe the consequences for those who compass David about?
options: The mischief of their own lips shall cover them
They shall find peace and mercy
They shall be exalted among men
questions.correctAnswer: The mischief of their own lips shall cover them
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:9 declares that the enemies’ own evil speech will bring judgment upon themselves, a biblical principle also found in Proverbs 26:27, Matthew 12:36, and Romans 2:16.

questions.question: According to Psalms 140:13, who shall give thanks unto God's name?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:13 states that the righteous will give thanks to God's name, reflecting the biblical truth that gratitude and worship belong to the upright, as also seen in Psalm 34:1, Psalm 111:1, and Hebrews 12:28.

questions.question: What does Psalms 140:2 say about the hearts of the violent men?
options: They imagine mischiefs continually gathered for war
questions.correctAnswer: They imagine mischiefs continually gathered for war
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:2 describes the violent men as continually plotting evil and gathering for conflict, highlighting the persistent nature of human sinfulness. This is consistent with Jeremiah 17:9, Romans 3:18, and James 4:1 about the sinful heart.

questions.question: In Psalms 140:8, what is the reason given for not granting the desires of the wicked?
questions.explanation: David asks God not to grant the wicked’s desires lest they exalt themselves, illustrating the danger of pride and self-exaltation as condemned in Proverbs 16:18, Isaiah 2:12, and James 4:6.

questions.question: How does Psalms 140:7 describe God’s role in David’s salvation?
questions.explanation: Psalms 140:7 calls God 'the strength of my salvation,' affirming God's active role as Savior and protector, a concept echoed in Exodus 15:2, Isaiah 12:2, and Hebrews 12:28.
